body.p: Which is not a disease of the skeletal system?

feedback.p: Incorrect. "Osteo-" refers to bone.
Incorrect. "Osteo-" refers to bone.
Incorrect. "Osteo-" refers to bone.
Correct. "Neuro-" refers to nerves and "osteo-" refers to bone.

body.p: Bones store calcium for use in the rest of the body. How is the level of blood calcium controlled?

input.choice: intake of calcium through milk and other products

feedback.p: Correct. Parathyroid hormone is the main regulator of blood calcium levels..
Incorrect. Although calcium moves in and out of bone via chemical reactions, these reactions are governed by cells.
Incorrect. Bones respond to force and friction, but this doesn’t regulate the calcium levels.
Incorrect. Although blood calcium levels are affected by absorption from the GI tract, this is not the main regulator.

body.p: Hematopoiesis is the:

feedback.p: Correct. Blood cells are formed in the bone marrow in a process called hematopoiesis.
Incorrect. Bones are reorganized by bone cells, but this is not hematopoiesis.
Incorrect. Body movement is called translocation or locomotion, not hematopoiesis.
Incorrect. The spinal column is formed very early in human development; hematopoiesis occurs throughout life.

body.p: Which structure in the skeletal system is responsible for stabilizing synovial joints via bone to bone connections?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Some bone to bone connections can occur through bone tissue, but not in synovial joints.
Incorrect. Cartilage cushions the ends of bones within the join.
Incorrect. Tendons connect muscles to bones.
Correct. The collagen-containing ligaments stabilize synovial joints.

body.p: Which structure in the skeletal system is responsible for shock absorption?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Bones support load.
Correct. The protein and fluid content llows it to compress, aiding in shock absorption.
Incorrect. Tendons connect muscles to bones.
Incorrect. Ligaments stabilize joints.

body.p: Which structure in the skeletal system is responsible for connecting bones to muscles?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Bones support load.
Incorrect. Cartilage cushions the articulation.
Correct. Stiff collagen filaments in tendons transmit loads from muscle to bones.
Incorrect. The less-stiff collagen-containing ligaments stabilize articulations.

body.p: Which direction is a majority of the appendicular skeleton from the axial skeleton?

feedback.p: Correct. The limbs are distal from the central part of the body.
Incorrect. Anterior means toward the front of the body, not the extremties.
Incorrect. Posterior means toward the back of the body, not the extremties.
Incorrect. Inferior means toward the feet, but the appendicular skeleton includes all the extremities, not just the legs and feet.

content.p: Choose if the following word is part of the axial or appendicular skeleton, or if it is not a bone at all.

response.feedback: Correct. The mandible is the jaw bone, part of the skull.
Incorrect. The mandible is the jaw bone, part of the skull.
Incorrect. The mandible is the jaw bone, part of the skull.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The fibula is in the leg.
Correct. The fibula is in the leg.
Incorrect. The fibula is a bone in the leg.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

response.feedback: Correct. The sternum is in the chest.
Incorrect. The sternum is in the chest.
Incorrect. The sternum is a bone in the chest.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The pectoral girdle connects the humerus to the rest of the skeleton, but is not considered part of the axial skeleton.
Correct. The pectoral girdle connects the humerus to the rest of the skeleton.
Incorrect. The pectoral girdle is a group of bones that connects the humerus to the rest of the skeleton.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Cruciate is not a bone of the axial skeleton and may or may not be a bone at all.
Incorrect. is not a bone of the appendicular skeleton and may or may not be a bone at all.
Correct. Cruciate refers to the cruciate ligament, not a bone.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The scapula is part of the pectoral girdle.
Correct. The scapula is part of the pectoral girdle, making it part of the appendicular skeleton.
Incorrect. The scapula is part of the pectoral girdle.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

body.p: Which part of the skeletal system has more articulations with greater range of motion?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The axial skeleton is central, and the appendicular skeleton includes the extremities, which tend to move more.
Correct. The extremities move much more than the central skeleton.
Incorrect. The extremities move much more than the central skeleton.

body.p: The axial skeleton is associated with which function?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.
Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.
Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.

Correct. Many bones of the axial skeleton protect internal organs such as the brain and thoracic cavity, all bones regulate calcium storage, and some bones of each of the axial and appendicular skeleton have red bone marrow for hematopoeisis.

body.p: Which classification of bone tissue has trabeculae?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Osteons are formed in compact bone.
Correct. Spongy bone has trabeculae (rod-like structures).
Incorrect. Only one of these classifications of bone has trabeculae.
Incorrect. One of these classifications of bone has trabeculae.

content.p: Choose the correct bone type for each of the following questions.

multiple_choice.body: What type of bone is the carpal?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Long bones are long, but the carpal bone in the wrist is a similar length in all directions.
Correct. The carpal bone in the wrist is a similar length in all directions.
Incorrect. Flat bones are plate-like.
Incorrect. The carpal bone is small and not especially strange in shape.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

multiple_choice.body: What type of bone is the femur?

response.feedback: Correct. The femur is the bone in the thigh and its length is very large compared to its width.
Incorrect. The femur runs the length of the thigh.
Incorrect. The femur is round and not flat.
Incorrect. The femur is relatively regular in shape.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

multiple_choice.body: which type of bone is the scapula?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The scapula is also known as the shoulder blade and is not considered short.
Incorrect. The scapula is also known as the shoulder blade and is not considered short.
Correct. The scapula (shoulder blade) is flat and plate-like.
Incorrect. The scapule is also known as the shoulder blade and has two prominent surfaces.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

multiple_choice.body: What type of bone is the humerus?

response.feedback: Correct. The humerus in the upper arm is a long bone.
Incorrect. The humerus is in the upper arm and the length of ths bone is much larger than its width.
Incorrect. The humerus is fairly round along its diaphysis..
Incorrect. The bone in the upper arm is relatively regular.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

multiple_choice.body: What type of bones are the vertebrae?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The vertebrae in the spinal column are a complex shape and not long and thin.
Incorrect. The vertebrae might be short in one dimension, but they are also complex in shape.
Incorrect. The body of the vertebrae may look flat, but they also have a variety of processes that come off of the main body.
Correct. The vertebrae in the spinal column are among the most irregular bones in the body.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

multiple_choice.body: What type of bone is the hip bone?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The hip varies significantly in its dimensions of length, width and thickness
Incorrect. The hip is not roughly the same length in every dimension.
Incorrect. Although sections of it might be considered flat, the hip bone has a more complicated structure.
Correct. The irregular bone of the hip allows for the ball and socket articulation.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

body.p: What is the transition between the diaphysis and epiphysis called?

feedback.p: Correct. This transition is where the bone grows during childhood.
Incorrect. A disk is an imprecise answer and could refer to many strucutures, although it is usually used in reference to vertebral disks.
Incorrect. Red bone marrow can be found inside various bones, but is not specific to the transition between diaphysis and epiphysis.
Incorrect. Yellow bone marrow can be found inside various bones, typically in the medullary cavity of long bones.

body.p: Which of the following is not an inorganic component of bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium is an elemental mineral and does not contain organic carbon.
Correct. Collagen is a protein, which is organic.
Incorrect. Phosphorus is an elemental mineral and does not contain organic carbon.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite contains calcium and phosphorus, but no organic content.

body.p: How are the organic and inorganic components of bone integrated?

input.choice: Hydroxyapatite molecules integrate with collagen fibers.
Cortical bone is all inorganic and spongy bone is all organic.
There are no organic components of bone, it is all calcium.

feedback.p: Correct. At the molecular level, the hydroxyapatite (with calcium and phosphate) binds with collagen fibers to form lamellae.
Incorrect. Both types of bone contain organic and inorganic compounds.
Incorrect. All macroscopic bone structures contain organic and inorganic parts.
Incorrect. Bone contains organic collagen as well as cells.

body.p: How is water integrated into cartilage?

input.choice: There is one water molecule per collagen protein.
A network of negatively charged glycosylated proteins attract water.
Blood vessels in cartilage contain the water.
There is a pocket for water that is two to five centimeters in diameter.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Water is attracted by the glycosylations of the glycoproteins, and many water molecules are involved.
Correct. Water is drawn into glycosylations, which are polar in their chemical nature, allowing them to interact well with the water .
Incorrect. There are no blood vessels in cartilage.
Incorrect. Water is incorporated at the molecular level, not at the macroscopic level.

body.p: Which is not part of mature bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The extracellular matrix of bone contains collagen.
Correct. Proteoglycans are part of mature cartilage or immature bone.
Incorrect. Bone contains osteocytes and is constantly being remodeled with osteoclasts and osteoblasts.
Incorrect. Blood vessels flow through bone to nourish the bone cells.

body.p: In osteogenesis imperfecta, which molecule is altered?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium levels may be altered, but the mutation occurs in a different molecule .
Incorrect. Mutations could occur in proteoglycans, but they do not cause osteogenesis imperfecta.
Correct. A mutation in the collagen protein prevents proper formation of the extracellular matrix.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite levels may be altered, but the mutation occurs in a different molecule.

body.p: Which nanostructure is responsible for compression resistance in bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium by itself does not resist compression.
Incorrect. Proteoglycans resist compressive forces, but mostly in cartilage.
Incorrect. Collagen resists tension, not compression.
Correct. The crystal hydroxyapatite resists compression.

body.p: Which molecule is responsible for compression resistance in cartilage?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mineralized calcium is present in bone.
Correct. Proteoglycans and the associated water resist compression in cartilage.
Incorrect. Collagen resists tensile force.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite resists compressive forces, but in bone. In cartilage, proteoglycans resist compression.

body.p: Which nmolecule is responsible for tensile strength resistance in bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium is part of hydroxyapatite, which resists compression in bone.
Incorrect. Proteoglycans are primarily used to resist compression in cartilage.
Correct. Collagen, since it has a coiled-coil triple helix, is resistant to tension.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite resists compression in bone.

body.p: Which cells secrete osteoid?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Osteoclasts cleave bone (remember the "c" in "clasts" matches the "c" in "cleave").
Incorrect. Osteocytes are sensor cells in bone.
Correct. Osteoblasts build bone (remember the "b" in "blasts" matches the "b" in "build").
Incorrect. Macrophages are immune cells.

body.p: Which cells transform within the bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Osteoclasts and osteocytes are different types of cells.
Correct. After building the bone, osteoblasts embed themselves in the bone and become osteocytes.
Incorrect. Osteocytes are the mature form of bone cells, they do not differentiate into anything else.
Incorrect. Osteoclasts and osteocytes are different types of cells.

body.p: Inhibiting the function of which cell type would best benefit osteoporosis?

feedback.p: Correct. Inhibiting osteoclasts would reduce the rate of bone loss.
Incorrect. Inhibiting osteocytes would mean you are inhibiting the force- sensing cells in the bone.
Incorrect. Inhibiting osteoblasts would slow bone growth and limit remodeling.
Incorrect. Macrophages are immune cells and inhibiting them won’t affect bone remodeling, but could have other negative consequences

body.p: Which is not part of mature cartilage?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mature cartilage contains collagen.
Incorrect. Mature cartilage contains proteoglycans.
Incorrect. Cartilage contains chondrocytes.
Correct. Cartilage does not contain blood vessels, which makes repair challenging and makes it take a long time.

content.p: Which of the following would be considered a macrostructure of compact bone?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Lamellae are microscopic mineralized fibrils.
Correct. Lamellae in compact bone form tubular structures called osteons.
Incorrect. Lamellae in spongy bone form trabeculae.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite minerals are molecular level structures.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

body.p: Where are osteocytes found within the osteons?

input.choice: there are no cells in the osteons

feedback.p: Correct. Lacunae are oriented around the central canal, parallel with the osteons.
Incorrect. Lamellae are mineralized fibrils.
Incorrect. The central canal contains vessels.
Incorrect. Cells are required to remodel compact bone, and resident osteocytes sense the forces applied to bone.

body.p: What is in the central canal formed by osteons in compact bone?

feedback.p: Correct. Blood vessels travel through the central canal of compact bone to provide nutrients and remove wastes to the osteocytes in the lacunae.
Incorrect. Spongy bone is a different bone structure than the compact bone that contains the central canal
Incorrect. Bone marrow is in contained within the spaces of spongy bone, or within the marrow cavity of a long bone.
Incorrect. Cartilage is found at the end of long bones, where they articulate.

body.p: Which bones are formed via intramembranous ossification?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation limited to a particular type of bone.
Incorrect. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation limited to a particular type of bone.
Correct. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation used only for flat bones, such as those in the skull.
Incorrect. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation limited to a particular type of bone.

body.p: For which type of fracture would serious reconstructive measures be needed?

feedback.p: Incorrect. A simple fracture can be set with a cast.
Incorrect. A greenstick fracture—a fracture that occurs in children when one side of a bone breaks, and the other side bends—can be set with a cast.
Correct. In a comminuted fracture, the bone shatters or breaks into several pieces, and must either be reconstructed or replaced.
Incorrect. A stress fracture is small, and may not require any treatment.

body.p: Increased levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) may cause what?

input.choice: low calcium levels in the bone
low calcium levels in the blood
increased loss of calcium to urine

feedback.p: Incorrect. High levels of PTH shifts the bone balance in favor of bone resorption.
Correct. High levels of PTH stimulate calcium to move from bone to blood.
Incorrect. Calcitonin shifts the bone balance in favor of bone deposition, so calcium is reduced in the blood.
Incorrect. High levels of PTH stimulate the body to retain calcium, not increase its loss.

body.p: Which hormones act against one another with calcium levels in children?

feedback.p: Correct. Parathyroid hormone and calcitonin can counteract each other in children, although calcitonin has little effect in adults.
Incorrect. Growth hormone and calcitonin do not regulate the same variable.
Incorrect. Insulin and calcitonin regulate different variables.
Incorrect. Adrenaline and calcitonin regulate different variables.

body.p: Which of the following is the most direct effect of vitamin D in regards to bone health?

input.choice: It increases calcium absorption from the GI tract.
It is a hormone that adds calcium to bones.
It stimulates blood flow within the bones.

feedback.p: Correct. Vitamin D helps absorb calcium in the GI tract. This, in turn, stimulates bone formation.
Incorrect. Low levels of parathyroid hormone (in adults), or calcitonin (in children) stimulate bone formation.
Incorrect. There are other hormones that have direct effects on osteoblasts.
Incorrect. Hormones are not known to change blood flow to the bones.

body.p: Which of the following is a genetic condition that affects bones?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Fractures are induced by trauma and are not genetic.
Incorrect. Osteoporosis has some genetic factors, but it is not a genetic condition.
Correct. Osteogenesis imperfectais a genetic condition that affects collagen in bone.
Incorrect. Osteomalacia is a nutritional imbalance, not a genetic condition.

body.p: Which condition would not be helped with an increase in dietary calcium and vitamin D?

feedback.p: Incorrect. With all of the demands of skeletal repair, it should help to increase dietary uptake of calcium.
Incorrect. The development of osteoporosis can be slowed by increasing blood calcium levels through dietary means.
Incorrect. Rickets is a condition in children caused by low blood calcium levels.
Correct. Osteoarthritis is a disease of the cartilage, not bone, so it will not be helped with extra calcium or vitamin D.

body.p: Why are older individuals encouraged to lift weights to help their bones and reduce the effects of osteoporosis?

input.choice: bones respond to and get stronger with force

feedback.p: Incorrect. That’s true, but bones themselves are force-responsive.
Correct. Bones are force-responsive.
Incorrect. Exercise may benefit endocrine health, but weight-bearing exercises are good for bone strength.
Incorrect. Exercise is good for appetite, but weight-bearing exercises are good for bone strength.

body.p: How can reduced force on the cartilage in articulations, such as that experienced by astronauts in microgravity, lead to cell loss in cartilage?

input.choice: There is reduced fluid motion to the cells embedded in the cartilage.
Cells migrate out of the cartilage if they aren't needed.
Cells crenate from the lack of mechanical force.
There are no cells in cartilage.

feedback.p: Correct. Since cartilage does not have blood vessels, compression is required to move fluid in and out of cartilage; fluid movement is required to move in nutrients, take away waste and provide mechanical stimulation.
Incorrect. Cells do not migrate out of the cartilage, instead the answer is related to lack of nutrients deliverys.
Incorrect. Cells do not crenate (shrivel up) due to lack of forces, instead the answer is related to lack of nutrient delivery.
Incorrect. There are no blood vessels, but there are cells in cartilage.

body.p: Tendons:

input.choice: are a continuation of skeletal muscle fascia
act as a storage pool for calcium

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is the function of ligaments.
Correct. This is how the connective tissue of the muscle connects strongly with the tendon.
Incorrect. Tendons are a connective tissue made mainly of collagen, but it is not mineralized.
Incorrect. Tendons are a connective tissue that are not lined with epithelial cells, but contain fibroblast cells and collagen.

body.p: The scapula is part of the:

feedback.p: Correct. The pectoral girdle connects the humerus to the rest of the skeleton and projections of the scapula contribute to this connection.
Incorrect. The upper limbs start with the humerus and include the humerus and all bones distal. The scapula does not fit into this category.
Incorrect. The pelvic girdle helps connect the femur to the rest of the skeleton, which is not a function of the scapula.
Incorrect. The lower limbs start with the femur and include the femur and all distal bones. The scapula does not fit into this category.

body.p: If a person fractures their ilium, they might have the most trouble:

feedback.p: Incorrect. The ilium is not a bone of the skull.
Incorrect. The ilium is not a bone of the thoracic cage.
Correct. The ilium is one of the bones that make up the hip bone. A fracture of the ilium could affect the ability of someone to walk.
Incorrect. The ilium is not a bone of the hand, wrist or arm.

body.p: CHow does the density and brittleness (a substance is brittle if a stress causes it to break/shatter before deforming) compare between spongy bone and compact bone.

input.choice: compact bone is less dense and less brittle
compact bone is less dense and more brittle
compact bone is more dense and more brittle
compact bone is more dense and less brittle

feedback.p: Incorrect. Compact bone has s greater density than spongy bone.
Incorrect. Compact bone has a greater density than spongy bone.
Correct. Compact bone is more dense, but also more brittle, such that enough stress will cause it to break instead of bend.
Incorrect. Compact bone is not less brittle that spongy bone. Compact bone is more likely to break than bend under a stress.

body.p: Spongy bone gets its name from:

input.choice: its ability to absorb significant water
its ability to compress greater than 30 percent of its width
K. Spongy, the first person to describe its structure
its structure of alternating trabeculae and space

feedback.p: Incorrect. Spongy bone has some water in the marrow spaces, but does not absorb water.
Incorrect. Spongy bone has some ability to deform with a force (stress) exerted on it, but it is much smaller than 30%.
Incorrect. This name is not an eponym, if it was it would be capitalized.
Correct. This structure makes it look like a sponge.

body.p: Articular cartilage would be found on a long bone’s

feedback.p: Correct. The epiphysis is the end of the long bone, where the synovial articulations would be found.
Incorrect. The shaft is generally not a site of synovial articulations.
Incorrect. The metaphysis is the section between the diaphysis and epiphysis and would not be the site of a synovial articulation.
Incorrect. The medullary cavity is a deep structure of bone and not directly involved in articulations.

body.p: If you “knock out your tooth,” which type of joint has come apart?

feedback.p: Correct. The tooth in its socket is generally considered synarthrosis joint as it is fairly immovable. Sometimes it is also considered an amphiarthrosis joint.
Incorrect. A synovial joint contains a synovial cavity, which is not found at the base of the tooth.
Incorrect. A diarthrosis is freely movable, which does not describe a tooth in its socket.
Incorrect. A saddle joint allows for significant movement, which does not describe a tooth in its socket.

body.p: Hydroxyapatite is:

input.choice: an organic mixture of type I and type II collagen
an inorganic mixture containing calcium and phosphate
responsible for the ability of long bones to flex

feedback.p: Incorrect. Hydroxyappatite is not a protein.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite is not found in tendons, unless small bones form in them.
Correct. It adds stiffness to bone.
Incorrect. Collagen is what allows flexibility, not the mineralization.

body.p: A main role of proteoglycans in bone is to:

input.choice: attract water that acts to cushion compression

feedback.p: Correct. Proteoglycans have charged groups on them that attract the polar water molecules.
Incorrect. Protegolycans are proteins with sugar groups attached. They do not mineralize bone.
Incorrect. Proteoglycans are separate from collagen and do not function in collagen polymerization.
Incorrect. Collagen stabilizes tendon attachments

body.p: The main role of osteocytes is to:

feedback.p: Correct. These cells sense the forces experiences by bone.
Incorrect. Osteoclasts reabsorb bone.
Incorrect. Osteoblasts build new bone.
Incorrect. Osteoblasts secrete collagen molecules.

body.p: If parathyroid hormone is abnormally high over a long period, you would expect:

feedback.p: Incorrect. Parathyroid hormone does not stimulate bone growth.
Incorrect. Parathyroid hormone raises plasma calcium levels.
Incorrect. This would not be affected by parathyroid hormone levels.
Correct. Parathyroid hormone would stimulate osteoclasts activity, making bones less dense and weaker.

body.p: What are two major bones (or sets of bones) that make up the skull?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The hyoid is a bone found in the neck. The cranium is a set of bones contained in the skull
Incorrect. The hyoid is a bone found in the neck. The mandible is a bone of the skull.
Incorrect. The occicles are found enclosed within the bones of the skull (they are bones of the inner ear), but are not considered major bones of the skull.
Correct. The skull is made up of the bones of the cranium along with the mandible.

body.p: Which of the following is the correct function of the ribs?

input.choice: Provides protection for the organs of the thorax
Provides protection for the spinal cord

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is the function of the mandible.
Correct. Providing protection for the organs of the thorax, such as the heart and lungs is the function of the ribs.
Incorrect. Some of the ribs articulate with the vertebrae, but do not protect them.
Incorrect. This is the function of the cranium.

body.p: Which of the following are parts of the thoracic cage?

feedback.p: Correct. The ribs and sternum are both parts of the thoracic cage.
Incorrect. The ribs are part of the thoracic cage but the vertebrae are part of the spine or vertebral column
Incorrect. The ribs are part of the thoracic cage but the cranium is part of the skull.
Incorrect. The ribs are part of the thoracic cage but the mandible is part of the skull.

body.p: What are two major bones of the pectoral girdle?

feedback.p: Correct. The clavicle and scapula are the two major bones of the pectoral girdle.
Incorrect. The two coxal bones are part of the pelvic girdle.
Incorrect. The tibia and fibula are bones of the lower leg.
Incorrect. The ilium and ischium are parts of the two coxal bones of the pelvic girdle.

body.p: Which bone is located on the lateral side of the forearm between the elbow and wrist?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The ulna is on the medial side of the forearm between the elbow and wrist.
Correct. The radius is on the lateral side of the forearm between the elbow and wrist.
Incorrect. The humerus extends from the scapula to the elbow.
Incorrect. The tibia is in the lower leg.

body.p: Which of the following bones is properly matched with its function?

input.choice: Scapula -- provide attachment for ligaments that allow movement of the wrist
Femur -- supports the movement of the forearm
Clavicle -- helps keep the shoulder in place
Ulna -- articulate with the clavicle and the humerus

feedback.p: Incorrect. The scapula is in the shoulder and articulates with the clavicle and humerus.
Incorrect. The femur provides attachment for the muscles of the lower limbs and buttocks.
Correct. The clavicle helps keep the shoulder in place.
Incorrect. The ulna forms the medial side of the forearm between the elbow and wrist.

body.p: Which classification of bone has a collection of specialized cells, organic extracellular matrix proteins, and inorganic salt crystals?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Compact bone has all three of these characteristics but so does spongy bone.
Incorrect. Spongy bone has all three of these characteristics but so does compact bone.
Correct. Both classifications of bone have these characteristics.
Incorrect. Both classifications of bone have these characteristics.

body.p: Which of the following is correctly paired with its description?

input.choice: Flat bones are formed by endochondral ossification.
Long bones are formed by intramembranous ossification.
Endochondral ossification is the formation of bone between layers of connective tissue.
Intramembranous ossification is the formation of bone between layers of connective tissue.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Flat bones are formed by intramembranous ossification.
Incorrect. Long bones are formed by endochondral ossification.
Incorrect. Endochondral ossification is the formation of bone from a hyaline cartilage blueprint.
Correct. Intramembranous ossification is the formation of bone between layers of connective tissue.

body.p: Which of the following is correctly matched with its components?

input.choice: Molecular level -- compact and spongy bone combine to form whole bone
Macromolecular level -- mineral crystals are embedded within collagen
Cell layer -- lamellae form osteons or trabeculae
Tissue level -- mineralized fibrils are organized into lamellae

feedback.p: Incorrect. Molecular level includes the mineral crystals.
Correct. The macromolecular level includes the hydroxyappatite forming within the collagen matrix.
Incorrect. Lamellae are formed into osteons or trabeculae at the macromolecular level.
Incorrect. Organ level is the combination of compact and spongy bone combined to form the whole bone.

body.p: What feature of the hydroxyapatite crystals allow them to easily exchange ions with the blood?

input.choice: They have a high volume to surface area ratio
They have a high surface area to volume ratio

feedback.p: Incorrect. They do add to the compressive strength of bone but this does not impact their ability to exchange ions.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite crystals do not have a high volume to surface area ratio.
Correct. Hydroxyapatite crystals have a large surface area compared to their volume, providing a large surface from which to exchange ions.
Incorrect. The fluoride crystals add more strength to the bone but can actually decrease the exchange of ions as fluoride is hard to remove from the crystal structure.

body.p: Which of the following is not a function of phosphorous?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Phosphorous is utilized to make ATP, which is a short term storage form of energy.
Incorrect. Phosphorous is needed for cell growth, especially for the replication of DNA, which has a sugar-phosphate backbone.
Incorrect. Phosphorous is part of RNA and DNA backbones.
Correct. Calcium is the element that plays a key role in blood clotting.

body.p: If a person was lacking Type I collagen which of the following would occur?

input.choice: Bones would have less bone marrow
There would be no effect on bone because Type I collagen is found in cartilage only

feedback.p: Incorrect. The bones would have less flexibility because collagen adds flexibility.
Correct. In bone formation a cartilage matrix must be deposited first.
Incorrect. This would not affect the bone marrow.
Incorrect. Type I collagen is the primary form of collagen in bone.

body.p: Which of the following is properly matched with its function?

input.choice: Osteoclasts -- break down and reabsorb bone
Osteoblasts -- deposit and build new bone
Osteocytes -- mature bone cells that act as force sensors
All of the above are correctly matched with their function.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.
Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.
Incorrect. Although true, this is not the best answer to this question.
Correct. These are all properly matched with their functions.

body.p: Which of the following fractures is not properly matched with its description?

input.choice: Greenstick fracture -- occurs in children when one side of a bone breaks, and the other side bends
Impacted fracture -- one end of the fractured bone is forced into the interior of the other end
Simple fracture -- ends of the broken bone break through the skin
Stress fractures -- incomplete fractures of the bone caused by over use

feedback.p: Incorrect. Greenstick fractures do occur in children when one side of a bone breaks, and the other side bends.
Incorrect. An impacted fracture does have one end of the bone forced into the interior of the other end.
Correct. Simple fractures do not have bone ends that break through the skin. That occurs in compound fractures.
Incorrect. Stress fractures are incomplete fractures of the bone caused by overuse.

body.p: Why do we splint a bone after a fracture?

input.choice: To prevent infection from an open wound
To minimize movement between the bone fragments

feedback.p: Incorrect. Splinting will decrease muscle strength because the muscle will atrophy due to disuse.
Incorrect. Although closing an open wound will reduce the risk of infections, most fractures do not cause open wounds.
Incorrect. Although splinting may decrease pain, this is not the main reason for splinting.
Correct. A bone will heal more quickly if its fragments are immobile.

body.p: Which of the following is true of rickets?

input.choice: It is mainly a problem of synovial joints
It most commonly results from vitamin D deficiency
It is caused by a lack of vitamin C

feedback.p: Incorrect. Rickets is a condition affecting children.
Incorrect. Rickets affects bone formation, and does not primarily affect joints
Correct. Rickets is caused by lack of vitamin D in children.
Incorrect. Scurvey is caused by a lack of vitamin C, not rickets.

body.p: Which of the following structures allow external mechanical information to be quickly transmitted to osteocytes?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Lacuna house the osteocytes.
Incorrect. Lamellae add strenght to bone.
Correct. Canaliculi are channels that allow for orces to transmit to the osteocytes.
Incorrect. Trabeculae add strength to spongy bone.
